content.body:
> <@shuyuguo:matrix.org> were there changes to using await? it looked like an exact mirror of the sync case, except plumbing through the `~async-dispose~` hint and awaiting disposable resources with that hint on block exit

No. The `~async-dispose~` plumbing was there when you reviewed Explicit Resource Management prior to Stage 3 since I'd left it in to support `AsyncDisposableStack`. The only changes I've made aside from adding the `using await` syntax were to incorporate editorial feedback that I already received on the sync version of the proposal since creating https://github.com/tc39/ecma262/pull/3000, so that the spec text shared between the two remains consistent.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @shuyuguo:matrix.org
were there changes to using await? it looked like an exact mirror of the sync case, except plumbing through the ~async-dispose~ hint and awaiting disposable resources with that hint on block exit
No. The ~async-dispose~ plumbing was there when you reviewed Explicit Resource Management prior to Stage 3 since I'd left it in to support AsyncDisposableStack. The only changes I've made aside from adding the using await syntax were to incorporate editorial feedback that I already received on the sync version of the proposal since creating https://github.com/tc39/ecma262/pull/3000, so that the spec text shared between the two remains consistent.

content.body: cool, that makes sense

content.formatted_body: I should clarify, there were minor changes to address Mathieu Hofman and erights concerns about any evaluated using await forcing an explicit await even if the initialized value is null or undefined, but that should be about it.

my understanding re process:

> Withdrawing Proposals, Reverting to Earlier Stages, and Adopting Proposals

> At any point in the process, a proposal champion may propose that a proposal be downgraded to an earlier stage or withdrawn. Consensus of the committee is necessary for these transitions.
content.formatted_body:
my understanding re process:

Withdrawing Proposals, Reverting to Earlier Stages, and Adopting Proposals

At any point in the process, a proposal champion may propose that a proposal be downgraded to an earlier stage or withdrawn. Consensus of the committee is necessary for these transitions.

I don't think so, but you can add the terms to the glossary at https://github.com/tc39/how-we-work/blob/main/terminology.md
in this context, in-band means within the source text, specifically within the import declaration
out-of-band would be things like HTTP headers, CLI flags, browser config, etc
OOB would be something like import maps: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/script/type/importmap

content.body: Ah, my bad.

> <@haxjs:matrix.org> ok. so if syntax is `async using`, no need to ban `await`?

We might need to ban `async using` in other places instead. See https://tc39.es/ecma262/#prod-ForInOfStatement, which needs to ban `async  of` because `async of => {}` is a legal arrow. `async using` would potentially require a complex cover grammar to deal with similar cases.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @haxjs:matrix.org
ok. so if syntax is async using, no need to ban await?
We might need to ban async using in other places instead. See https://tc39.es/ecma262/#prod-ForInOfStatement, which needs to ban async of because async of => {} is a legal arrow. async using would potentially require a complex cover grammar to deal with similar cases.

content.body: I should have clarified re: https://github.com/tc39/proposal-explicit-resource-management/pull/140 whether it requires consensus. Given the algorithm changes in ForBodyEvaluation and CreatePerIterationEnvironment are essentially no-ops, removing them has no observable effect on runtime semantics.
am warming up to the option of prohibiting '.cause' on SuppressedErrors - I think it's a conceptual mismatch for SuppressedError
i'm still not clear on why it's not a cause when we all keep describing it as the thing that caused the suppression
(i.e., read the options bag and throw if it's a present)
it doesn't cause the suppression - the use of the syntax causes the suppression
in `using`, sure. but not necessarily in every use of SuppressedError
content.formatted_body: in using, sure. but not necessarily in every use of SuppressedError

content.body: that's the only use of SuppressedError
in the spec, but this is something users will use separately
ok but it is a mismatch for the only case it gets used in the spec, so it's bad fit
even if users might do a different thing where it would get used in a different way
ljharb: perhaps you're thinking of "cause" to mean "caused mechanically the SuppressedError to be created and thrown"
content.formatted_body: ljharb: perhaps you're thinking of "cause" to mean "caused mechanically the SuppressedError to be created and thrown"

content.body: yes, that's what i'm thinking of
the cause is what caused the SuppressedError
whereas waldemar and kevin (and myself) think of "cause" as, like, the conceptual reason of an error
which in the case kevin mentioned is a SyntaxError, right?
yes, what ron is saying right now
it is not a linear relationship
the core disagreement i think is how do developers understand "cause"
is it this linear causality chain, or is it a simpler "whatever effected it to be thrown mechanically"
i would argue the latter
yeah so far we've had folks on both sides

I think the only acceptable use for "cause" is "we hit an error condition because of a prior error condition", and that is _not_ what it means here - here it is "we had an error, and then a different error which would prevent surfacing the first one"
content.formatted_body: I think the only acceptable use for "cause" is "we hit an error condition because of a prior error condition", and that is not what it means here - here it is "we had an error, and then a different error which would prevent surfacing the first one"

content.body: to be clear my core motivation here is "it should not be possible to have an error that has two potential conceptual causes - .error and .cause"
there are some good argument being made that `.cause` may not be right to replace `.error`
content.formatted_body: there are some good argument being made that .cause may not be right to replace .error

content.body: but that still doesn't mean it makes sense to have an error instance with all of cause/error/suppressed
`error` is not the "cause", neither is `supressed` the "cause". My use of the term "causes a suppression" does not imply `cause` in this case, it implies the cause of a behavior.
content.formatted_body: error is not the "cause", neither is supressed the "cause". My use of the term "causes a suppression" does not imply cause in this case, it implies the cause of a behavior.

content.body:
> <@ljharb:matrix.org> to be clear my core motivation here is "it should not be possible to have an error that has two potential conceptual causes - .error and .cause"

`SuppressedError` _does_ have two conceptual causes. I'm more in favor of banning `cause` because it results in _three_ conceptual causes.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @ljharb:matrix.org
to be clear my core motivation here is "it should not be possible to have an error that has two potential conceptual causes - .error and .cause"
SuppressedError does have two conceptual causes. I'm more in favor of banning cause because it results in three conceptual causes.

content.body: sure, i can accept that reframing
My understanding is `cause` should be used by developers to specify the low-level "cause" of a high-level error. So `SuppressedError` is not the case.
content.formatted_body: My understanding is cause should be used by developers to specify the low-level "cause" of a high-level error. So SuppressedError is not the case.

content.body: HE Shi-Jun: the consequence of removing InstallErrorCause is, the `options` parameter is ignored, so if you do `new SuppressedError('foo', null, null, { cause })` the `cause` property is not read or installed on the resulting error
content.formatted_body: HE Shi-Jun: the consequence of removing InstallErrorCause is, the options parameter is ignored, so if you do new SuppressedError('foo', null, null, { cause }) the cause property is not read or installed on the resulting error

content.body: (compared to other native errors, most of which check for `undefined` for things like `message`).

so we‚Äôre just abandoning pretense of equality between browsers and non-browser participants of tc39?

content.body:
> <@rbuckton:matrix.org> In English, `ID` (as in, "show me your ID") is an initialism, not an abbreviation, for "Identity Document", https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Identity_document, if that matters.

And Id is the abbreviation for Identifier or Identity
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @rbuckton:matrix.org
In English, ID (as in, "show me your ID") is an initialism, not an abbreviation, for "Identity Document", https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Identity_document, if that matters.
And Id is the abbreviation for Identifier or Identity

content.body: It‚Äôs also the dual of ego.
Precisely. Though `id` is a psychological term.
content.formatted_body: Precisely. Though id is a psychological term.

content.body: ljharb: not at all. i believe _some_ action is needed than continuing bikeshedding on the name
content.formatted_body: ljharb: not at all. i believe some action is needed than continuing bikeshedding on the name

content.body: Unfortunately, `ID` vs `Id` is a very long-running debate. I lean on the side of `ID` makes sense if you're using SCREAMING_SNAKE_CASE (e.g., for constant values), because you are capitalizing every letter, while `Id` should be what you use for camelCase/PascalCase identifiers.
content.formatted_body: Unfortunately, ID vs Id is a very long-running debate. I lean on the side of ID makes sense if you're using SCREAMING_SNAKE_CASE (e.g., for constant values), because you are capitalizing every letter, while Id should be what you use for camelCase/PascalCase identifiers.

content.body: and a perfectly reasonable option is ‚Äúidentifier or code‚Äù. Let‚Äôs just do one of those - i don‚Äôt want to argue about it either, but that doesn‚Äôt mean i want to concede.
and if you think my trying to make progress on a name bikeshed is equivalent to discarding all non-browser participants' opinions, i don't know what to tell you
i think that any claim of intending to ship a willful violation that disregards consensus is a dangerous precedent to set, and isn't worth buying a few weeks or months of a faster decision.
does it matter that there's already precedent for `Id` in the spec?

content.body:
> <@ljharb:matrix.org> i think that any claim of intending to ship a willful violation that disregards consensus is a dangerous precedent to set, and isn't worth buying a few weeks or months of a faster decision.

content.body: so the two largest JS ecosystem conventions use `Id` fairly consistently.
content.formatted_body: so the two largest JS ecosystem conventions use Id fairly consistently.

content.body: i can temper my response as "by shipping time, if there isn't consensus, i'm going to ship `calendarId` instead of let that block shipping Temporal"
content.formatted_body: i can temper my response as "by shipping time, if there isn't consensus, i'm going to ship calendarId instead of let that block shipping Temporal"

content.body: NodeJS isn't _entirely_ consistent on how they handle initialisms, but `Id` seems fairly consistent.
content.formatted_body: NodeJS isn't entirely consistent on how they handle initialisms, but Id seems fairly consistent.

content.body:
> <@rbuckton:matrix.org> If it helps, not only does the DOM use `Id` capitalization, so does NodeJS.

Yeah @rbuckton that was my argument, the ecosystem (whether web or server side) are already using that capitalisation, theres quite large precedent for it already.

content.body: it does seem like a foregone conclusion doesn't it?  I must say I have a hard time understanding the controversy

cleaning up the notes, I'm just sort of shocked how reasonable we all sound, and how we're making clear logical arguments on all sides. I sometimes get caught up in the emotions in the moment and lose track of that! And it's been amazing to work with the transcriptionist--when I was helping with notes, there was so little to fix.
like, how do we all make such interesting coherent comments improvised? We're pretty good!
I was wondering how it must feel like to transcribe a meeting like ours
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I was wondering how it must feel like to transcribe a meeting like ours

content.body: with no context whatsoever
well, I think they were reading our corrections and getting better over the course of the meeting
anyway it'd be great to get more feedback from everyone, especially people correcting notes, on the transcriptionists this time
i appreciate the tempering
my feedback is that I love the transcriptionists
notes require much less work to fix, and also I don't have to run the bot
it's so much better. there's always going to be tiny things to polish but none of that detracts from how much better the experience is with the transcriptionist.
